messageBody:
Hi Kirill,
Ya the article mentioned by you discuss the same thing that I read somewhere. I don't
remember the exact url now.
I wanted to know the different views on this topic and the disscussion here was
satisfactory.

Thanks and regards,
Parag

Kirill Maximov wrote:

> On 0, Parag Shetye <parag@...> wrote:
>
> Hello,
>
> As far as I understand, you've taken this code from the article
>
> http://www.fawcette.com/javapro/2002_01/magazine/features/hkirk/default_pf.asp
>
> (IMHO, this article shall be moved from the section "Articles"
> to section "Test Pattern Articles" on the JUnit site. It is named
> "Discover Your Inner Classes ")
>
> But in this article this code is offered as a "bad smell" example,
> and an alternative is shown - usage of an inner class to encapsulate
> fixture and expected result (see the article for details).
>
> This approach is quite close to that offered by Mike Clark.
>
> This approach (inner class usage) solves at least the
> first limitation. About the second - I agree that all tests
> shall pass and in this specific case when getBatchLabel() works
> incorrectly I see no trouble to fix the problems one-by-one
> until the test will pass as a whole.
>
> With best regards,
> KIR
>
> > A Growing Problem
> >
> > The typical way of handling test cases in JUnit is to create a class
> > with methods beginning with "test". For example, we could create the
> > methods testNullAccount() and testEmptyAccount() to handle cases where
> > the account object is null and empty, respectively. This approach is
> > satisfactory for a few test cases, but what if the number of test cases
> > grows to 50 or even 500? It seems that there is always another test case
> > I should test for. Having this many methods becomes unmanageable. The
> > situation gets ugly.
> >
> > You might work around this limitation by placing all test cases and
> > assert statements sequentially inside a single method. This approach
> > suffers from two limitations. The first limitation is the need to
> > replicate the test code for every test case. Even if you have only two
> > or three lines of code per test case, the size of the method will
> > mushroom and become hard to maintain (and read). See example below (
> > Taken from JavaPro ) -
> >
> > public void testCreateBatchLabelNoInnerClass() {
> >
> > try {
> > BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> > "20010530", "A13", "1" );
> > assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
> > "A13-1 EXP. 05/01" ) ) ;
> > } catch (Exception e) {
> > assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
> > }
> >
> > try {
> > BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> > "20010530", "A13", "" );
> > assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
> > "A13 EXP. 05/01" ) ) ;
> > } catch (Exception e) {
> > assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
> > }
> >
> > try {
> > BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> > "20011231", "A13", "1" );
> > assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
> > "A13-1 EXP. 12/01" ) ) ;
> > } catch (Exception e) {
> > assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
> > }
> >
> > try {
> > BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> > "20010101", "A13", "1" );
> > assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
> > "A13-1 EXP. 01/01" ) ) ;
> > } catch (Exception e) {
> > assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
> > }
> >
> > try {
> > BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> > "20010101", "A123", "99" );
> > assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
> > "A123-99 EXP. 01/01" ) ) ;
> > } catch (Exception e) {
> > assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
> > }
> >
> > try {
> > BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> > "2001530", "A999", "" );
> > } catch (Exception e) {
> > assert( "Wrong Exception thrown: " + e,
> > e.getClass().equals(
> > BadDateException.class )) ;
> > }
> >
> > try {
> > BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> > "20010530", "913", "1" );
> > } catch (Exception e) {
> > assert( "Wrong Exception thrown: " + e,
> > e.getClass().equals(
> > BadLotException.class )) ;
> > }
> >
> > // etc
> >
> > }
> >
> > The second limitation is that JUnit will stop the testing after the
> > first failure?the remaining test cases won't be executed.
> >
> > What can be the solution on these two limitations?
> >
